{"step_by_step_thinking": "The cell-rich zone is a part of the dental pulp, which is the part of the tooth that contains nerves and blood vessels. The cell-rich zone is so named because it contains a high concentration of cells compared to other areas of the pulp. The most abundant cells in this area are undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, which have the potential to differentiate into a variety of other cell types, including odontoblasts, which are responsible for dentin formation.", "answer_choice": "D. Undifferentiated mesencymal cells"}
